Emergency Response Program
The Fort Worth plant maintains a written emergency response plan designed to protect workers and public safety as well as the environment during an emergency. The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of formaldehyde. These procedures address notification and emergency signals, specific containment actions, and proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel following an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the plant has procedures to address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment. All visitors and contractors receive some level of orientation to instruct them in emergency signals and actions to be taken during an emergency. More than half of the production employees are trained to Hazardous Materials Operations level to apply defensive measures to hazardous materials emergencies. These personnel are sufficiently trained to deal with most hazardous materials emergencies that might occur in this facility. In the event of more serious emergencies, the same personnel are trained and prepared to assist the efforts of other emergency response personnel in a variety of support roles. All employees are trained as first responders at the awareness level and in procedures for cleaning up small spills based on their work assignments.
Overall emergency response programs are coordinated with the Fort Worth Fire Department. This coordination includes briefings and information sharing to address specific concerns in the event of an incident at the plant and drills to practice skills. Prevention Program
The Nouryon Surface Chemistry Facility has implemented a combination of engineering and administrative controls which make the occurrence of a formaldehyde release highly unlikely. Control measures in place significantly reduce the possibility of smaller, less serious releases. Process equipment design considers the consequences of a variety of process scenarios and incorporates safeguards to prevent or minimize the effect of deviations in normal operating conditions. Process equipment including vessels, piping, pumps, control systems and safety systems are inspected and maintained in accordance with a mechanical integrity program. Trained personnel perform critical operations in accordance with standard operating procedures. The following is a summary of the accident prevention programs in place at the Fort Worth Plant:
• Preventive maintenance and testing of vessels, piping, pumps, control systems and safety systems through the Mechanical Integrity program helps to ensure that structural failures do not occur in process equipment.
• Reaction vessels and storage tanks are protected from overpressure with pressure relief devices or conservation vents.
• Each reactor and storage tank vent to a control system that scrubs, removes, and/or destroys gases and vapors.
• Process conditions are monitored from a control room where alarms warn trained personnel of abnormal operating conditions.
• Secondary containment is available in the forms of dikes and drain sumps.

Management of Change
The site's management of change program is intended to review and evaluate changes to process chemistry, operating conditions or limits, equipment, and procedures before changes are made so as to prevent unexpected adverse impacts. The management of change program uses a quantitative risk assessment to determine the significance of the change. This risk level assessment determines the levels of authorization required to approve the action. Design review checklists are used to evaluate different types of changes to prevent new hazards being created or equipment changes which are not suited to the service as it exists in the process. Another feature of the management of change program is that it verifies and documents that procedures, records, and equipment information are updated and that personnel affected by the change are informed of and trained in the change.

Incident Investigation
All incidents that result in, or could have reasonably resulted in, a release of a hazardous material, a fire or explosion in a covered process area, major property damage, adverse environmental impact, or serious personal injury be reported and promptly investigated. By investigating accidents and near misses, important lessons are learned. Corrective actions can then be implemented to prevent similar events in the future. Incident investigations are documented, and recommendations tracked to their completion. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years to facilitate their use during PHA updates and revalidation.

Mechanical Integrity
The Fort Worth Plant assures the mechanical integrity of critical operations equipment such as pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps, and safety systems through its mechanical integrity program. The basic aspects of the program include: (1) training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures. In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process. Maintenance personnel receive training in (1) overviews of the process and its hazards, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) safe work practices to help ensure that they perform their jobs in a safe manner. Equipment deficiencies, once identified, are corrected prior to further operation of the equipment, or a management team will determine and prescribe how the equipment may continue safely in operation. As part of the mechanical integrity program, quality assurance measures are incorporated into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper material and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Contractor Safety Program
The Fort Worth Plant employs contractors to perform special construction projects or supplement the maintenance workforce when needed. All contractors receive orientation training depending on the scope, nature, and location of their work. Contractors’ selection considers the existence and effectiveness of their safety programs and performance. Contractors undergo orientations where they are made aware of basic plant rules and safety policies, workplace hazards in the area they will work, safe work practices applicable to the jobs, and basic emergency response procedures. During this initial orientation, contract employees are instructed to report any hazards their work may create or that they discover during the course of their work. Contractors are periodically evaluated to ensure they are fulfilling their safety obligations.

This includes significant changes in process equipment or procedures or upon completing the construction of new process facilities. The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment in service. Operating Procedures
The Fort Worth plant maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) initial startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) startup following maintenance activities or following an emergency shutdown. Operating procedures are used as a reference by experienced operators and a training resource in training new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate. Operating procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. When creating or reviewing operating procedures, a team of personnel review and comment on the draft’s accuracy and completeness. Procedures are available to operators and other personnel in work areas where process operations are performed.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Off-Site Consequence Analysis
The Fort Worth Plant has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards and risks associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each new and altered process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. Methodologies used to perform these evaluations include the hazard and operability study (HAZOP) and layer of protection analysis (LOPA). These analyses are conducted using cross-functional teams with operations and engineering expertise. Team members identify and evaluate hazard scenarios, ranking each scenario's risk level with respect to event likelihood and severity. The team also evaluates prevention and mitigation measures and makes appropriate recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures if they are judged necessary. The site management team reviews the PHA team's findings and recommendations. The management team establishes priorities for implementation of PHA recommendations based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the team. This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios with the highest risk receive more immediate attention. Process Safety Information
Technical information on process equipment, technology, and chemicals is maintained and used to ensure safe operation of the covered processes. These documents address chemical properties and their associated hazards, limits for critical process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design and configuration details. Specific departments are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information. Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and other known hazards associated with inadvertently mixing of chemicals. For specific covered process areas, there are documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperatures, pressures). Operators ensure that the process is maintained within these limits using reliable process controls and monitoring instruments, emergency relief systems and two stage scrubber system, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., emergency shutdown systems). The finished products are water-based surfactants with highly efficient dispersant properties. Specific applications include agricultural product formulations to retard sedimentation of water dispersible granules such as herbicides, insecticides, and fungicides. In the same unit, formaldehyde is diluted in water to a concentration less than 1% and blended with another water-based surfactant to abate an unusually strong odor.

There is one EPA RMP regulated toxic chemical used at the facility. Formaldehyde is the only RMP regulated toxic material present in amounts greater than the threshold quantity. No regulated flammables, above threshold quantities, are present at the facility. The facility is regulated under Level 2 RMP requirements as it is not subject to OSHA Process Safety Management regulation, 29 CFR 1910.119, and the covered RMP process does not fall under the prescriptive North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes listed in Section 68.10i of the RMP regulation.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs in place at the facility are part of the high standards striven for by Nouryon Surface Chemistry, LLC. These high standards include:
• Operating in compliance with required environmental permits and regulations.
• Operating and maintaining the assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
• Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
• Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility.

Introduction and Policies
Nouryon Surface Chemistry LLC is committed to worker and public safety as our first priority. It is our belief that those things that contribute to safe operations also improve quality and reduce costs. This commitment to safety can be seen in the investment of resources made for accident prevention. These efforts include employee training and a systematic approach to safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement effective controls to prevent foreseeable releases of dangerous substances. To supplement these controls, additional safeguards are provided to reduce the impact of a release should one occur in spite of all precautions. Plant employees and managers are trained to take appropriate action in an emergency to protect the welfare of the public, our employees, and the surrounding environment.
The purpose of this Risk Management Plan is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency response plans in the event of an accidental release, the five-year accident history of the facility and planned changes to improve safety at the plant.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
The Nouryon Surface Chemistry Facility, located in Fort Worth, Texas, is operated by Nouryon to manufacture a variety of specialty surfactants.
The facility is situated on approximately five acres in north Fort Worth. The immediate area surrounding this plant is a natural gas wellhead to the north, industrial development including Ferro Corporation and a residential zoned areas to the west, commercial/residential zoned areas to the south, and the Trinity River to the east.
